pull.title: locking for Misbehave() and other cs_main locking fixes
pull.body: In several places in main.cpp, synchronized data structures are accessed without cs_main being held.

events.message:
lock cs_main for State/Misbehaving

ProcessMessage calls State(...) and Misbehaving(...) without holding the
required lock; add LOCK(cs_main) blocks.

lock cs_main for chainActive

ActivateBestChain uses chainActive after releasing the lock; reorder operations
to move all access to synchronized object into existing LOCK(cs_main) block.

events.body: hmph. peppering cs_main in the middle of functions sounds like a formula for lock inversion.  Perhaps Misbehaving() should get its own lock internally and not depend on cs_main?

A separate nodestate cs is definitely doable; there's a fair amount of code that would need to hold cs_main and nodestate, but no new locks ever need to be acquired within the scope of a cs_nodestate lock. I'll draft a refactor.

rename.to: locking for Misbehave() and other cs_main locking fixes

events.body: I created a separate mutex, cs_misbehavior. cs_misbehavior is only locked either directly inside a cs_main lock or along with no other locks, so there shouldn't be any deadlocks (and DEBUG_LOCKORDER isn't complaining). cs_misbehavior is the sole mutex guarding the nMisbehavior and fShouldBan fields; modifications to the mapBlockSource container are guarded by both cs_main and cs_misbehavior so that either lock suffices to perform lookups safely.
@kazcw I don't see your cs_misbehaviour, but I think the code here is fine as is. We certainly need a separate lock for node states, but I would delay that until the net refactors are done.
utACK 719de56,  and I concur that I do not see `cs_misbehavior`

utACK 719de56
Going to merge this, the nit can be done later.

comments.body: You can use pindexNewTip->nHeight instead of creating an extra variable.

> You can use pindexNewTip->nHeight instead of creating an extra variable.

ping @kazcw
